item.title: Elgato is printing the bandwidth and USB type on its cables
item.description:
Elgato is printing the bandwidth and USB type on its cables:

https://www.theverge.com/2023/11/6/23948486/usb-c-cables-marking-speed-power-delivery-elgato

"I wish all manufacturers did this."

item.title: Starfish are mostly head
item.description:
Starfish are mostly head:

https://www.cnn.com/2023/11/02/world/starfish-head-body-plan-scn/index.html

"[N]ew genetic research suggests ... that sea stars are
largely heads that lack torsos or tails and likely lost
those features evolutionarily over time.  The researchers
said the bizarre fossils of sea star ancestors, which
appeared to have a kind of torso, make a lot more sense in
evolutionary terms in light of the new findings.

...

 'When we compared the expression of genes in a starfish
 to other groups of animals, like vertebrates, it appeared
 that a crucial part of the body plan was missing,' [one
 of the researchers] said. 'The genes that are typically
 involved in the patterning of the trunk of the animal
 weren't expressed in the ectoderm. It seems the whole
 echinoderm body plan is roughly equivalent to the head in
 other groups of animals.'"

item.title: Nice short summary of isolated, closed, and open systems

item.title: comm(1)
item.description:
comm(1):

https://www.johndcook.com/blog/2019/11/24/comm-set-theory/
https://man.openbsd.org/comm.1

comm(1) showed up in Version 4 AT&T UNIX. I can't believe
I didn't know about this until recently.

item.title: N-9?
item.description:
N-9?:

https://physics.aps.org/articles/v16/186
https://www.sciencenews.org/article/physicists-elusive-isotope-nitrogen-9

"With seven protons and two neutrons, the lopsided atomic
nucleus of nitrogen-9 pushes the limits of what can even
be considered a nucleus at all.

...

Protons and neutrons, the subatomic particles that make up
atomic nuclei, are essentially glued together by the
strong nuclear force ...[, b]ut the force can't
hold together nuclei that have wildly skewed ratios of
protons to neutrons. Too many of either particle -
especially protons, which repel each other due to their
positive charge - and the nuclear bucket starts to
overflow.

Beyond this overflow point, which physicists call the
'drip line,' nuclei cannot fully bind their particles.

...

Finding a nucleus as far beyond the drip line as
nitrogen-9 - five protons beyond - was surprising ...
[because, u]ntil now, scientists had only ever found
isotopes up to four protons beyond the drip line."

item.description:
